title: Statistical Analysis Script for RETREAT Cohort
text:
Code
# ---
# R SCRIPT FOR STATISTICAL ANALYSIS: RETREAT COHORT
#
# Purpose: This script loads the prepared analysis dataset and performs all
#          statistical analyses as outlined in the SAP (Version 2.0).
#          This includes descriptive statistics, Kaplan-Meier analysis,
#          and Cox proportional hazards modeling to assess predictors of
#          pregnancy.
# ---
Code
# Load necessary libraries

# Check if packages are installed, and install them if not
packages <- c("survival", "tidyverse", "lubridate", "conflicted", 
              "gtsummary", "survminer", "here", "MASS","coxphf",
              "gtreg","labelled","ggstatsplot","patchwork","ggsci",
              "easystats","ggforestplot")
for (pkg in packages) {
  if (!require(pkg, character.only = TRUE)) {
    install.packages(pkg)
    library(pkg, character.only = TRUE)
  }
}
conflict_prefer_all("dplyr",quiet=TRUE)
Code
# Set global options for gtsummary and gtreg
theme_gtsummary_language("en", big.mark = "")
theme_gtsummary_journal("jama")
# theme_gtsummary_continuous2(
#   statistic = "{median} ({p25}, {p75})",
#   set_theme = TRUE
# )
options(scipen=999)
Code
# 2. LOAD PREPARED DATASET ----
# -----------------------------

# Load the final dataset created by the data preparation script
final_file_data_path <-list.files(
  path = here::here(),
  recursive = TRUE,
  include.dirs = TRUE,
  pattern = "retreat_analysis_data.RData",
  full.names = TRUE
)


load(final_file_data_path)

title: Statistical Analysis Script for RETREAT Cohort
text:
Incidence Rate Calculation


Code
# Incedence rate calculation for the cohort using Poisson regression
TABLE<-glm(
  event ~ 1, 
  data = retreat_final |> 
    mutate(person_years=(t_stop-t_start)/365.25), 
  family = poisson(log),
  offset = log(person_years / 100)
  ) |> 
  gtsummary::tbl_regression(
    intercept = TRUE,
    exponentiate = TRUE,
    tidy_fun = \(x, ...) tidy_robust(x, vcov = cov, ...),
    label = list(
      "(Intercept)" ~ "Estimate per 100 person-years"
    ),
    conf.level = 0.95,
    pvalue_fun = label_style_pvalue(digits = 3)
  ) |> 
  add_nevent() |> 
  modify_table_body(
    ~ .x |> 
      mutate(
        exposure = exposure*100,
      )
  ) |> 
  modify_column_unhide(exposure) |> 
  modify_header(!!!list(
    label ~ "**Pregnancy incidence rate**",
    exposure ~ "**Exposure**")#Total Person-Years of Follow-Up
    ) |>
  modify_caption("**Incidence Rate**")
TABLE






Incidence Rate


Pregnancy incidence rate
Exposure
Event N
IRR (95% CI)
p-value




Estimate per 100 person-years
1,375
184
13.4 (11.6 to 15.5)
<0.001



Abbreviations: CI = Confidence Interval, IRR = Incidence Rate Ratio








Based on observing 184 pregnancies over a total of 1,375 person-years of exposure, the study found a statistically significant pregnancy rate of 13.4 pregnancies for every 100 people followed for one year. We can be 95% confident that the true rate for the population this sample represents is between 11.6 and 15.5 pregnancies per 100 person-years.

title: Statistical Analysis Script for RETREAT Cohort
text:
Kaplan-Meier Survival Analysis


Code
retreat_baseline <- retreat_baseline |> drop_na()
# Create a survival object using the baseline (one-row-per-person) data
# This is appropriate for plotting overall survival and by baseline characteristics.
surv_obj_baseline <- Surv(time = retreat_baseline$t_stop, event = retreat_baseline$event)

# Kaplan-Meier fit for the whole cohort
km_fit_overall <- survfit(surv_obj_baseline ~ 1, data = retreat_baseline)

# Plot the overall survival curve
overall_km<-ggsurvplot(
  km_fit_overall,
  data = retreat_baseline,
  risk.table = TRUE,
  conf.int = FALSE,
  surv.median.line="hv",
  title = "Time to Pregnancy (Overall Cohort)",
  xlab = "Time in Days",
  ylab = "Pregnancy-Free Probability",
  legend = "none"
)




Code
for(VAR in non_num_vars) {
  
# Get variable labels for the selected covariate
var_label <- labelled::var_label(retreat_baseline[[VAR]])
var_value <- as.character(sort(unique(retreat_baseline[[VAR]])))
  # Create a survival object for the current covariate
  surv_obj <- Surv(time = retreat_baseline$t_stop, event = retreat_baseline$event)
  
  # Fit the Kaplan-Meier model for the current covariate
  km_fit <- survfit(surv_obj ~ get(VAR), data = retreat_baseline)
  
  # Plot the KM curve
  FIG<-ggsurvplot(
    km_fit,
    data = retreat_baseline,
    risk.table = TRUE,
    pval = TRUE,
    conf.int = FALSE,
    surv.median.line="hv",
    title = paste("Time to Pregnancy by",var_label),
    xlab = "Time in Days",
    ylab = "Pregnancy-Free Probability",
    legend.title = "",
    legend.labs = var_value,
    palette="jama"
  )
  if(VAR == non_num_vars[1]){
    ls_fit<-list()
    ls_fig<-list()
  }
  ls_fit[[var_label]] <- km_fit
  ls_fig[[var_label]] <- FIG
}




Code
(overall_km[["plot"]] | ls_fig[[1]][["plot"]] | ls_fig[[2]][["plot"]]) / (ls_fig[[3]][["plot"]] | ls_fig[[4]][["plot"]] | ls_fig[[5]][["plot"]]) + 
  plot_annotation(
    title = "Figure 2: Stratified Kaplan-Meier Curves",
    tag_levels = 'A'
    )

title: Statistical Analysis Script for RETREAT Cohort
text:
Cox Proportional Hazards Models


Code
retreat_final<-retreat_final |> drop_na()
# Covariates of interest for the Cox models
covariates_of_interest <- c("age", "childfuture", "live2y", "alcprob", "single", "married", "compprim", "abvprim")
num_vars<-names(
  retreat_final|>
    select(any_of(covariates_of_interest)) |>
    select_if(is.numeric)
  )

non_num_vars<-names(
  retreat_final|>
    select(any_of(covariates_of_interest)) |>
    select(-any_of(c(num_vars)))
)

# from non_num_vars get non-numeric variables for the model that are only 2-levels
non_num_vars_2level <- non_num_vars[sapply(retreat_baseline[non_num_vars], function(x) length(unique(na.omit(x))) == 2)]

# Create the survival object for the time-dependent analysis
# This uses the start-stop data format.
retreat_final$surv_obj_tdc <- Surv(time = retreat_final$t_start, 
                     time2 = retreat_final$t_stop, 
                     event = retreat_final$event)



Effect of changing contraception (Time-Dependent Analysis)

Primary Objective results


Code
# A priori adjusted model as per SAP
cox_model_tdc <- coxph(
  surv_obj_tdc ~ change_contr_tdc,
  data = retreat_final
)

# Display the results in a tidy table
TABLE_unadjusted<-tbl_regression(
  cox_model_tdc, exponentiate = TRUE,
  show_single_row = any_of(non_num_vars),
  label = list(change_contr_tdc ~ "Un-adjusted")) |> 
  italicize_labels() |> 
  italicize_levels() |>
  add_global_p(pvalue_fun = label_style_pvalue(digits = 3)) |> 
  bold_p()




Code
# A priori adjusted model as per SAP
cox_model_tdc <- coxph(
  as.formula(paste(c("surv_obj_tdc ~ change_contr_tdc",covariates_of_interest),collapse = " + ")),
  data = retreat_final
)

# Display the results in a tidy table
TABLE_adjusted<-tbl_regression(
  cox_model_tdc, exponentiate = TRUE,
  show_single_row = any_of(non_num_vars_2level),
  pvalue_fun = label_style_pvalue(digits = 3),
  label = list(change_contr_tdc ~ "Adjusted")
  ) |> 
  italicize_labels() |>
  add_global_p() |> 
  bold_p()

# Combine the unadjusted and adjusted tables
TABLE_combined <- tbl_stack(
  tbls = list(TABLE_unadjusted, TABLE_adjusted),
) |> 
  modify_header(label ~ "**Model**") |>
  modify_caption("**Cox Proportional Hazards Model for the main effect of Time-Dependent Contraception Change**") |> 
  modify_table_body(
    ~ .x |> 
      filter(
        variable=='change_contr_tdc'
      )
  ) |> 
  modify_spanning_header(
    estimate ~ "**Effect of Contraception Change**"
  )

Code
TABLE$table_body |> 
  mutate(label=factor(label,levels=rev(unique(label))),
         groupname_col=factor(groupname_col,levels=(unique(groupname_col)))) |> 
  ggplot() +
  aes(x=estimate,y=label)+
  geom_errorbar(aes(xmin = conf.low, xmax = conf.high,colour = groupname_col),
                  position=position_dodge(0.5),width=0.3)+
  ggforce::facet_col(~groupname_col,space="free",scales = "free_y")+
  geom_point(aes(color=groupname_col,shape = factor(ifelse(p.value<0.05,'Significant','non-significant'),
                                levels=c('Significant','non-significant'))),
             size=3)+
  scale_shape_manual(name=NULL,values = c(16,21)) +
  scale_color_nejm(name="Models") + 
  scale_fill_nejm(name="Models") + 
  ggforestplot::theme_forest()











Code
# -------------------------

# Use cox.zph() on the final multivariable model for baseline predictors
ph_test <- cox.zph(cox_model_tdc)
TABLE<-ph_test[["table"]] |> 
  as.data.frame() |> 
  tibble::rownames_to_column() |> 
  tbl_listing()

# A non-significant p-value (e.g., > 0.05) for each covariate and for the GLOBAL
# test suggests that the proportional hazards assumption holds.
# We can also plot the residuals to visually inspect the assumption.
ggcoxzph(ph_test)












Exploratory analysis of baseline predictors


Code
# Note: We use the 'retreat_baseline' dataset here as these are fixed covariates.
TABLE_Univariate<-tbl_uvregression(
  data = retreat_baseline,
  method = coxph,
  y = Surv(t_stop, event),
  exponentiate = TRUE,
  show_single_row = any_of(non_num_vars_2level),
  include = any_of(c(covariates_of_interest)),
  pvalue_fun = label_style_pvalue(digits = 3)
  ) |> 
  bold_labels() |> 
  italicize_levels() |>
  add_global_p(pvalue_fun = label_style_pvalue(digits = 3)) |> 
  bold_p(t = 0.05)

# Based on univariable p-values <= 0.20 (and keeping 'age'), we build the model.
TABLE_Univariate$table_body |> 
  filter(p.value <= 0.2) |> pull(variable) -> selected_vars

merge(covariates_of_interest,covariates_of_interest) |> 
  mutate(comb=paste(x,y,sep="*")) |> 
  filter(!grepl("educgp\\*alcprob|\\*alcprob|alcprob\\*|alcprob\\*educgp",comb)) |> 
  pull(comb) -> selected_vars_

selected_vars<-c(selected_vars,selected_vars_)
selected_vars<-c(covariates_of_interest,selected_vars_)

FOMULAR<-as.formula(paste("Surv(t_stop, event) ~ ",paste(selected_vars,collapse = "+")))
cox_model_multi <- coxph(
  FOMULAR,
  data = retreat_baseline
)
n_obs <- nobs(cox_model_multi)
cox_model_multi <- stepAIC(
  cox_model_multi, direction = "both",
  k = log(n_obs),
  trace = FALSE)


cox_model_multi <- coxph(
  as.formula(paste("Surv(t_stop, event) ~ (",paste(c(
    cox_model_multi[["terms"]][[3]],"abvprim"
  ),collapse = "+"), ")")),
  data = retreat_baseline
)

TABLE_Multivariable<-tbl_regression(
  cox_model_multi, 
  exponentiate = TRUE,
  show_single_row = any_of(non_num_vars_2level),
  pvalue_fun = label_style_pvalue(digits = 3)
  ) |> 
  bold_labels() |> 
  italicize_levels() |>
  add_global_p() |> 
  bold_p() |>
  modify_header(label ~ "**Characteristic**") |>
  modify_caption("**Multivariable Cox Proportional Hazards Model**")

# Combine the univariable and multivariable tables
TABLE_combined_multi <- tbl_merge(
  tbls = list(TABLE_Univariate, TABLE_Multivariable),
  tab_spanner = c("**Univariable Analysis**", "**Multivariable Analysis**")
) |> 
  modify_header(label ~ "**Characteristic**") |>
  modify_caption("**Cox Proportional Hazards Model for Baseline Predictors of Pregnancy**")

title: Study Design
Study Design
text:
Baseline Characteristics

Socio-Demographics Characteristics


Code
# Get Numeric Variables
num_vars<-names(
  dt_|>
    select(-any_of(keys)) |>
    select_if(is.numeric)
  )

non_num_vars<-names(
  dt_|>
    select(-any_of(c(keys,num_vars)))
)

dt_ |>
  tbl_summary(
    by=country,
    digits = num_vars ~ style_sigfig,
    type = list(
      all_continuous() ~ "continuous2",
      num_vars ~ "continuous2"
      ),
    statistic = list(
      all_continuous() ~ c(
        "{N_nonmiss}",
        "{mean} ({sd})",
        "{median} ({p25}, {p75})",
        "{min}, {max}"),
      all_categorical() ~ "{n} ({p}%)"
      ),
    missing = "ifany",
    missing_text = "Missing/Not Applicable"
  ) |>
  add_overall(
    col_label="**Overall**  <br>N = {style_number(N)}",
    last=TRUE
  ) |>
  bold_labels() |>
  func_store_gt_table()

# Get Numeric Variables
num_vars<-names(
  dt_|>
    select(-any_of(keys)) |>
    select_if(is.numeric)
  )

non_num_vars<-names(
  dt_|>
    select(-any_of(c(keys,num_vars)))
)

dt_ |>
  tbl_summary(
    by=country,
    digits = num_vars ~ style_sigfig,
    type = list(
      all_continuous() ~ "continuous2",
      num_vars ~ "continuous2"
      ),
    statistic = list(
      all_continuous() ~ c(
        "{N_nonmiss}",
        "{mean} ({sd})",
        "{median} ({p25}, {p75})",
        "{min}, {max}"),
      all_categorical() ~ "{n} ({p}%)"
      ),
    missing = "ifany",
    missing_text = "Missing/Not Applicable"
  ) |>
  add_overall(
    col_label="**Overall**  <br>N = {style_number(N)}",
    last=TRUE
  ) |>
  bold_labels() |>
  func_store_gt_table()

  dt_|>
    select(-any_of(keys)) |>
    select_if(is.numeric)
  )

  dt_|>

dt_ |>
  tbl_summary(
    by=country,
    digits = num_vars ~ style_sigfig,
    type = list(
      all_continuous() ~ "continuous2",
      num_vars ~ "continuous2"
      ),
    statistic = list(
      all_continuous() ~ c(
        "{N_nonmiss}",
        "{mean} ({sd})",
        "{median} ({p25}, {p75})",
        "{min}, {max}"),
      all_categorical() ~ "{n} ({p}%)"
      ),
    missing = "ifany",
    missing_text = "Missing/Not Applicable"
  ) |>
  add_overall(
    col_label="**Overall**  <br>N = {style_number(N)}",
    last=TRUE

  bold_labels() |>
  func_store_gt_table()

Biostatistics | Bioinformatics | Data Science | Pharmacometrics | Clinical Research | Clinical Data Management | Generative Artificial Intelligence
Statistical Analysis & Modeling | Dataset Management  | Clinical Trials |Epidemiology  | Healthcare Analytics | Public Health  | Data Visualization | Automated Reporting  | Scientific Collaboration |Scientific Communication |Mentorship  






A highly motivated and results-oriented Biostatistician and Data Scientist with over 7 years of experience in designing, analyzing, and reporting on clinical trials and cohort studies, including extensive work with large and complex longitudinal datasets. Passionate about leveraging advanced statistical methodologies, particularly in R, to drive evidence-based decision-making in health research. Proven ability to lead statistical planning, create linked datasets, and contribute significantly to scientific publications. Adept at collaborating with multidisciplinary teams to deliver impactful research findings, with a keen interest in contributing to mental health research. Committed to clear communication and fostering a culture of data-driven research through mentorship and training.




Highly analytical and results-oriented professional with advanced proficiency in statistical analysis and modeling using R (including pipeline development), SAS (including macro development), Python, and Stata.
Proven expertise in end-to-end dataset management, from extraction, cleaning, and processing to validation and the creation of complex linked and harmonized datasets using R, Python, SAS, and SQL.
Possesses comprehensive experience in the design and execution of clinical trials and epidemiological studies, including study design, statistical analysis plan development, sample size calculation, randomization, and the analysis of diverse public health data (HIV, TB, COVID-19, mental health).
Skilled in translating complex data into actionable insights through the development of automated reports with Quarto and interactive dashboards with R Shiny.
A strong scientific collaborator and mentor with a record of co-authoring peer-reviewed publications, presenting research findings, and training junior statisticians.

title: 👋 Welcome — I’m Marothi Peter LETSOALO
text:
My professional focus involves leading innovative analytical initiatives within infectious disease research to support data-driven public health action. I operate at the confluence of Biostatistics and Artificial Intelligence, employing methodologies such as causal inference, Bayesian modeling, and machine learning to analyze complex real-world health data. My research and applied work span several critical domains: leveraging data science for infectious disease epidemiology in Africa; developing data-driven solutions to promote equitable maternal and child health in sub-Saharan Africa; investigating the role of vaginal microbiota and immune factors in infection risk through immuno-epidemiology; applying advanced analytics to enhance insights from clinical trials and translational research; and championing the integration of AI and open data principles into global health research, education, and systems.
My doctoral research develops a biostatistical and AI-driven framework for equitable maternal health in sub-Saharan Africa. Through CADRE-Africa, I actively contribute to capacity building by mentoring researchers and guiding data architecture and reproducible research practices.
